news_summary: Scientists have unraveled the century-old mystery behind a North Atlantic cold spot, advancing our understanding of oceanic climate patterns.
news_summary_fr: Des scientifiques ont élucidé le mystère centenaire d'une tache froide dans l'Atlantique Nord, ce qui nous permet de mieux comprendre les régimes climatiques océaniques.
news_summary_es: Los científicos han desvelado el misterio centenario que se oculta tras una mancha fría en el Atlántico Norte, avanzando así en nuestra comprensión de los patrones climáticos oceánicos.

articles.title: Researchers solve a century-old North Atlantic cold spot mystery
articles.summary: A century-old North Atlantic cold patch is now linked to a long-term slowdown in the AMOC, the climate-regulating conveyor belt of ocean water. Only weakened-AMOC models match observed temperature and salinity patterns, overturning recent model trends. This slowdown affects weather systems, jet streams, and marine life throughout the Northern Hemisphere. The discovery sharpens climate forecasts and highlights a major shift already underway.
articles.content:
For more than 100 years, an unusually cold pool of water south of Greenland has stood out against the overall warming of the Atlantic Ocean. This persistent chill has prompted long-running scientific debate. A new study now points to a long-term weakening of a major ocean circulation system as the underlying cause.

Researchers at the University of California, Riverside report that only one mechanism can simultaneously account for observed temperature trends and changing salinity levels: a slowdown in the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, or AMOC. This large-scale system influences global climate by carrying warm, salty surface waters northward and sending cooler waters back toward the tropics at depth.

"People have been asking why this cold spot exists," said UCR climate scientist Wei Liu, who led the study with doctoral student Kai-Yuan Li. "We found the most likely answer is a weakening AMOC."

Because the AMOC functions like a climate-regulating conveyor belt, any reduction in its flow means that less heat and salt reach the sub-polar North Atlantic. The result is the cooling and freshening that researchers observe south of Greenland.

Century of Data Reveals a Long-Term Trend

A slowing AMOC reduces the transport of warm, salty water, leading to cooler and less saline surface conditions. For this reason, temperature and salinity records are valuable indicators of the circulation's strength.

Liu and Li examined approximately a century of these measurements, since direct AMOC monitoring only began about 20 years ago. Using these long-term records, they reconstructed past changes in the circulation and compared the results to nearly 100 climate model simulations.

Their analysis, published in Communications Earth & Environment, shows that only the models reflecting a weakened AMOC are consistent with the real-world data. Simulations that assumed a stronger current did not reproduce the observed cooling.

"It's a very robust correlation," Li said. "If you look at the observations and compare them with all the simulations, only the weakened-AMOC scenario reproduces the cooling in this one region."

Cooling, Salinity Decline, and Broad Climate Impacts

The study also found that lower salinity in the region aligns with a slowing AMOC, reinforcing the conclusion that reduced transport of warm, salty water is driving the trend.

The implications reach far beyond the immediate area. The South Greenland anomaly is one of the most sensitive regions to shifts in ocean circulation. Its cooling influences weather patterns across Europe by altering rainfall and affecting the jet stream, a high-altitude air current that helps guide storm systems and regulate temperatures throughout North America and Europe.

Marine ecosystems may also be affected, as variations in salinity and temperature shape the environments where species can survive.

Clarifying a Debate in Climate Modeling

The findings help resolve a disagreement among climate modelers about whether the South Greenland cooling is primarily caused by ocean dynamics or by atmospheric influences such as aerosol pollution. Some newer models argued for the latter and predicted a strengthening AMOC as aerosol emissions declined. However, those models did not match the observed cooling pattern.

"Our results show that only the models with a weakening AMOC get it right," Liu said. "That means many of the recent models are too sensitive to aerosol changes, and less accurate for this region."

By addressing that discrepancy, the study improves confidence in climate projections, especially those involving Europe, where AMOC-related shifts have significant influence.

Using Indirect Clues to Reconstruct Ocean History

The research also demonstrates how scientists can draw meaningful conclusions from indirect evidence. Although direct AMOC measurements are limited, temperature and salinity data offer a reliable window into long-term ocean circulation changes and can help refine predictions for future climate conditions.

"We don't have direct observations going back a century, but the temperature and salinity data let us see the past clearly," Li said. "This work shows the AMOC has been weakening for more than a century, and that trend is likely to continue if greenhouse gases keep rising."

Growing Influence of the South Greenland Cold Spot

As the climate continues to shift, the cold spot south of Greenland may become an increasingly important factor in future climate behavior. By identifying its origins, researchers hope to provide better preparation for the changes ahead.

"The technique we used is a powerful way to understand how the system has changed, and where it is likely headed if greenhouse gases keep rising," Li said.

This discovery improves climate forecasts and understanding of broad environmental impacts, including weather and marine ecosystems, benefiting society's ability to prepare for climate change.
articles.personality_title: Scientists explain century-old cold spot in North Atlantic linked to ocean slowdown
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For over 100 years, a cold patch of water south of Greenland has puzzled scientists because it stayed unusually cool while the rest of the Atlantic Ocean warmed. This cold spot sparked many questions about what causes it.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of California, Riverside studied temperature and salt levels in the North Atlantic over the past century. They found that the cold spot is caused by a slowdown in the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), a large ocean current that moves warm water north and cold water south. This slowdown means less warm water reaches that area, making it cooler and less salty.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it solves a long-standing mystery and shows that the AMOC has been weakening for more than 100 years. Since the AMOC affects weather in Europe and North America by influencing the jet stream and rainfall, understanding its changes helps improve climate predictions. It also alerts us to effects on marine life that depend on temperature and salt levels.

**What's next step** – Scientists will use this new understanding to refine climate models, making weather and climate forecasts more accurate. They will also monitor the AMOC more closely to see how it changes in the future, especially as greenhouse gases continue to rise.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A century-old cold patch south of Greenland is caused by a long-term slowdown of a key ocean current, improving climate forecasts and understanding of changing weather patterns.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques expliquent une zone froide centenaire dans l’Atlantique Nord liée au ralentissement de l’océan
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis plus de 100 ans, une zone d’eau froide au sud du Groenland intrigue les scientifiques car elle reste anormalement froide alors que le reste de l’Atlantique se réchauffe.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Californie à Riverside ont étudié la température et la salinité de l’Atlantique Nord sur un siècle. Ils ont découvert que cette zone froide est due à un ralentissement de la circulation méridionale de retournement de l’Atlantique (AMOC), un courant océanique qui transporte l’eau chaude vers le nord et l’eau froide vers le sud. Ce ralentissement fait que moins d’eau chaude arrive dans cette région, la rendant plus froide et moins salée.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle résout un mystère vieux d’un siècle et montre que l’AMOC faiblit depuis longtemps. Comme l’AMOC influence la météo en Europe et en Amérique du Nord en modifiant le jet-stream et les précipitations, comprendre ses changements aide à améliorer les prévisions climatiques. Cela montre aussi les effets possibles sur la vie marine qui dépend de la température et de la salinité.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont utiliser cette nouvelle connaissance pour améliorer les modèles climatiques et rendre les prévisions plus précises. Ils surveilleront aussi de près l’AMOC pour suivre ses évolutions, surtout avec la hausse continue des gaz à effet de serre.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une zone froide centenaire au sud du Groenland est causée par un ralentissement de longue durée d’un courant océanique clé, ce qui améliore les prévisions climatiques et la compréhension des changements météorologiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos explican una zona fría centenaria en el Atlántico Norte vinculada a la desaceleración oceánica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante más de 100 años, una zona de agua fría al sur de Groenlandia ha desconcertado a los científicos porque permanece inusualmente fría mientras el resto del Atlántico se calienta.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de California en Riverside estudiaron la temperatura y salinidad del Atlántico Norte durante un siglo. Descubrieron que esta zona fría se debe a una desaceleración de la Circulación Meridional de Vuelco del Atlántico (AMOC), una gran corriente oceánica que mueve agua cálida hacia el norte y agua fría hacia el sur. Esta desaceleración hace que menos agua cálida llegue a esa zona, volviéndola más fría y menos salina.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque resuelve un misterio de un siglo y muestra que la AMOC se ha debilitado durante mucho tiempo. Como la AMOC afecta el clima en Europa y América del Norte al influir en la corriente en chorro y las lluvias, entender sus cambios ayuda a mejorar las predicciones climáticas. También señala posibles efectos en la vida marina que depende de la temperatura y salinidad.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos usarán este nuevo conocimiento para mejorar los modelos climáticos y hacer pronósticos más precisos. También vigilarán la AMOC para observar cómo cambia en el futuro, especialmente con el aumento de gases de efecto invernadero.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una zona fría centenaria al sur de Groenlandia es causada por una desaceleración prolongada de una corriente oceánica clave, mejorando las predicciones climáticas y la comprensión de los cambios en el clima.
